Breeding adult.description: Pacific Loons are smaller with a thinner bill than Common Loons. Breeding birds have a barred back and vertical barring on the neck whereas breeding Common Loons have a checkered back and a striped collar.

Nonbreeding/immature.description: On the neck of nonbreeding/immature Pacific Loons, the gray meets the white in a straight line running down the neck, whereas for Common Loons in winter, this smooth pattern is broken by a partial white collar.

Breeding adult.description: Red-throated Loons are smaller with a thinner bill than Common Loons. They also tends to hold their dainty bills pointed upward, above horizontal.

Nonbreeding adult.description: Nonbreeding Red-throated Loons are smaller with a thinner bill and more white on the face than Common Loons. They also tends to hold their dainty bills pointed upward, above horizontal.

Breeding adult.description: Breeding Yellow-billed Loons have a thicker yellow bill than Common Loons that have a slimmer black bill.

Immature.description: Yellow-billed Loons are larger than Common Loons with a blockier head. Immature Yellow-billed Loons also have a paler bill than immature Common Loons.

Nonbreeding.description: Double-crested Cormorants have more slender, orange or yellow bills with hooked tips (the hook can be hard to see at distance). They are more uniformly dark than Common Loons.

Adult.description: Western Grebes have much longer necks than Common Loons, with needlelike yellowish bills.

Breeding male.description: Male Common Mergansers show considerably more white on the body than Common Loons, and in flight both sexes show white patches in the wings that Common Loons lack.
